sourceDesc.p:
This publication constitutes a remediation of the printed REED collections - Inns of Court, Ecclesiastical London, and Civic London to 1558. Information on original sources for transcriptions can be accessed via the Document Descriptions.

Mary C. Erler

projectDesc.p: Records of Early English Drama (REED) is an international scholarly project that is establishing for the first time the context from which the drama of Shakespeare and his contemporaries grew. Founded in 1976, REED has worked since then to locate, transcribe, and edit historical documents containing evidence of drama, secular music, and other communal entertainment and ceremony from the Middle Ages until 1642, when the Puritans closed the London theatres.

REED London Online is a prototype online collection developing from the Records of Early English Drama (REED) in partnership with the Canadian Writing Research Collaboratory (CWRC) and supported by Bucknell University. It aims to establish an openly accessible online scholarly and pedagogical resource of London-centric documentary, editorial, and bibliographic materials related to performance, theatre, and music spanning the period 1100-1642. With support from an NHPRC-Mellon Planning Grant for Digital Edition Publishing Cooperatives and CANARIE Research Software Program grants, REED London is creating new environments for scholarly presentation of archival materials gathered from legal, ecclesiastical, civic, political, and personal archival sources in and around London. The objective of the REED London project team is to build a stable, extensible publication environment that optimizes access to these compiled materials in ways that respond to scholars’ research interests across disciplines. Consulting with other planning grant recipients will be invaluable to ensuring that REED London’s production and publication environment is in line with standards laid out in the NHPRC-Mellon grant objectives. It is hoped that the progress REED London and CWRC make will also inform the larger dialogue about best practices among funded teams.

div.ab: Item yt was orderyd vpon the informacion and requeste of master Chamberleyn that Iohn Greves and Iohn hollyngbrydge parishe clerkes & also williamson late one of the waytes of this Cytie shalbe warned to be here the nexte Courte daye/

Item yt was agreid that there shalbe a Comen counseyll here holden vpon Mondaye nexte comyng at ix of the clock for the grauntyng of ij xvnes for the present that is to be geven to the quenes maiestie by the Cytie att the tyme of her coronacion & for ij xvnesthe provysion of wood & other necessaries for the cominaltye of the seid Cytie/

Item the wardeyns bothe of the parishe clerkes & also of the mynstrelles of this Cytie were here presentlye charged to call seuerallye their hole ffelowships togither & to put theym selfes with all convenyent Spede in good & perfytt redynes to do the beste & moste commenlye servyce that they can for the honour of the seid Cytie/ att the quenes maiesties fyrste comyngeaccession entry of Elizaabeth I, 28 November vnto the same/ And mr Altham mr Malorye mr Marten & mr Rowe Aldremen were assigned by the Courte to appoynt their stondynges & places & to take order with theym for their decent behauour in the doinge of their seid servyce & to geve theym notyce of the tyme therof/
div.note: The shreves of london to Receyve the quene at her graces first Entre in to Middlesex/
div.ab:
Item ys was agreid that bothe Master Shreves of this Cytie shall Receyve the quenes Maiestie att the vtter parte of the Shere of Middlesex wherof they be also Shreves at the tyme of her highnes entree into the same
Shere in their Cotes of velvett with their Chaynes of gold aboute their neckes and whyte Roddes in their handes whiche roddes they muste kysse and delyuer theym ioyntlye to her grace & Receyving theym bak ageyn from her grace the order is that they muste place theym selfes amongest the gentlemen and so ryde furthe before her Maiestie tyll she come vnto theym ^mayer & Aldremen and then they to take their places with my maisters the Aldermen/
Item willelmus Aston haberdasher recognovit se debere Iohanni Sturgeon Camerario xl li. bone &c. soluit &c.

The Condicion &c. that if the saide Recognitour at any tyme hereafter do not permyt or suffer any manner of enterlude or stage play to be made or played within his mansyon howse yarde garden or other place or places that he nowe keapethe and hathe or that he hereafter shall holde occupy or keape within the Cytey of London or the Libertyes thereof vnles he shalbe lycensyd by the Lorde Mayour of the sayde Cyty for the tyme beynge So to do that then &c.
div.note: Comyners apoyntyd to devyse pageauntes against the quenes maiestes Coronacion /
div.ab:
Item this day the worshipfull Comyners herevnder namyd were nomynatyd appoyntyd & chardgid by the hole Courte to take the chardge Travell & paynes to cause at the Cytyes costes and chardges all the places hereafter mencionyd to be very well and semely trymmyd & deckyd
for the honour of the Cyty agaynste the commynge of our Soueraigne Lady the Quenes maiesty that nowe is to her Coronacion thorroughe the Cyty with pageauntes fyne payntynge and Riche clothes of arras syluer and golde in suche and lyke manner & sorte as they were trymmyd agaynst the commyng of our late Soueraigne lady Quene mary to her Coronacion and moche better if it conveynyently may be done where vnto they agreinge grauntyd to do theire Indeavors That is to sey

row.cell: for the Condyt in Cornehill and the Stokes/
for the greate Condyt in Cheape
for the lyttle Condyt in Cheape/

div.ab: Item this day Richarde Grafton Richard Grafton, printer and historian and ffraunces Robynson grocers Richard Hilles merchaunttayllour and Lyonell ducket mercer were assignyd and apoyntyd by the Courte here to survey the doynges and devyses of all the other Comyners of this Cyty which are already apoyntyd to make and devyse suche pageauntes in sundry places of this Cytye agaynste the quenes maiestes commynge to her Coronacion as heretofore hathe byn accustomyd at the lyke tyme and to reforme alter or adde vnto the same as they with thadvyse of suche as they shall call vnto them shall think good and to make reporte here the nexte Courte day by a platte of all theire opynyons and doynges therein and then to vnderstande here what some of money the Cyty hathe in a redynes towardes the doynge therein

Item forasmoche as the paynters of this Cyty dyd vtterly refuse to newe paynte and trym the greate Condyt in Cheape agaynste the Quenes Maiestes comynge to her Coronacion for the Some of xxty markes yt was therefore Orderyd and agryed by the Courte here thys day that the Surveyours of the same shall cause it to be coueryd with Clothes of arras and suche other Ryche Clothes as they can geat and cause certayne Scutchins of the quenes highenes armys to be fynely made & set vpon the same and david playne hed warden of the paynters was commaundyd to attende vpon the said Surveyors of the Condyt & the Surveyors of all the other pageauntes of the Cyty & to help them with his Advyse & workemen for reasonable wages to the best of his powre wherevnto he wyllyngely agryed & promysyd so to do/
Item yt was Orderyd and agryed that Richard Bucland haberdasher shall cause the Carpenter to set vp the Skafold in Saynte Dunstanes Churcheyard
London & lez pore/ in ffletestrete for the childern of the howse of the pore by the day & not be greate and that he se that he and his men do labour honestly and that he kepe well the Reconynge of theire chardges

Item yt was agryed that the bachelers of the mercers Company shalbe permyttyd to stande Togither in Chepe syde dyrectely ouer agaynste the Masters of the same Company on the further syde of the Strete there at the Quenes commynge to her Coronacion

div.p: For Williamson (f 87v), see also The Records, pp 834–5, from Repertory 14, ff 61v and 63v (under 1557–8). This record may be biographical only but is included here because of the earlier records. For the common council order, referred to on f 90v, for two fifteenths to be collected for the city’s costs at Elizabeth I’s coronation, see the transcription immediately above from Journal 17, f 101. The ff 90v–1 records deal above all, however, with Elizabeth’s accession entry on 28 November 1558, for which, see the Introduction, p xxviii, and Appendix 1 under 1558–9. On f 97 there is a modern pencil note beside the first entry transcribed, in the right margin: ‘Stage Plays.’ For other 1558 records related to the January 1558/9 coronation, see ff 102 (15 December, the fence around the Cheapside Cross to be taken down) and 102v (coronation-day dinner service).

For printer and historian Richard Grafton (f 99), see p 1416, endnote to LMA: COL/CA/01/01/014 ff 112–12v, 113, 118–18v, 113v, 138v–9, 162v, 166v–7, 191, 191v. The mayor in 1558–9, Thomas Leigh, was a mercer, hence the special mention on ff 103v–4 of the bachelors of the Mercers’ Company. The children of the house of the poor (f 104) were either from St Bartholomew’s Hospital or from Christ’s Hospital.
